task-wr.title: Installing Reboot-Required Patches Using the CLI
task-wr.shortdesc: You can install reboot-required patches using the CLI.

step.cmd: Log in as Keystone user admin to the active controller.

info.p: Log in as user wrsroot to the active controller and source the script /etc/nova/openrc to obtain administrative privileges as described in .

step.cmd: Verify that the patches are available using the sw-patch query command.

codeblock.systemoutput: ï»¿ Patch ID Patch State ========================= =========== TITANIUM_15.12_PATCH_0001 Available TITANIUM_15.12_PATCH_0002 Available TITANIUM_15.12_PATCH_0003 Available
TITANIUM_15.12_PATCH_0001 is now in the repo

stepresult.p: The patch is now in the Partial-Apply state, ready for installation from the software updates repository on the impacted hosts.

step.cmd: Apply all available patches in a single operation.

codeblock.systemoutput: TITANIUM_15.12_PATCH_0001 is now in the repo
TITANIUM_15.12_PATCH_0002 is now in the repo
TITANIUM_15.12_PATCH_0003 is now in the repo

info.p: In this example, there are three patches ready for installation from the software updates repository.

step.cmd: Query the patching status of all hosts in the cluster.

info.p: You can query the patching status of all hosts at any time as illustrated below. Note that the reported status is the accumulated result of all applied and removed patches in the software updates repository, and not just the status due to a particular patch.

codeblock.systemoutput: Hostname IP Address Patch Current Reboot Required Release State ============ ============== ============= =============== ======= ===== compute-0 192.168.204.12 Yes No 15.12 idle controller-0 192.168.204.3 No Yes 15.12 idle controller-1 192.168.204.4 No Yes 15.12 idle

stepresult.p: For each host in the cluster, the following patch status fields are displayed:

dd.p: Indicates whether there are patches pending for installation or removal on the host or not. If Yes, then all relevant patches in the software updates repository have been installed on, or removed from, the host already. If No, then there is at least one patch in either the Partial-Apply or Partial-Remove state that has not been applied to the host.
Indicates whether the host must be rebooted or not as a result of one or more patches that have been either applied or removed, or because it is not patch current.
Indicates the running software release version.

li.p: U77159 / US83068 mention log server here?install-failed - The operation failed, either due to a patch error or something killed the process. Check the patching.log on the node in question.
install-rejected - The node is unlocked, therefore the request to install has been rejected. This state persists until there is another install request, or the node is reset.

dd.p: Once the state has gone back to idle, the install operation is complete and you can safely unlock the node.

stepresult.p: In this example, compute-0 is up to date, no patches need to be installed and no reboot is required. By contrast, the controllers are not patch current, and therefore a reboot is required to install the patch.

step.cmd: Install all pending patches on controller-0.

info.p: Before patching a controller node, you must transfer any active services running on the host to the other controller. Only then it is safe to lock the host.

stepxmp.p: You must lock the target host, controller, compute, or storage, before installing patches.

note.p: You can use the sudo sw-patch host-install-async hostname command if you are launching multiple installs in parallel.

stepxmp.p: Unlocking the host forces a reset of the host followed by a reboot. This ensures that the host is restarted in a known state.

stepresult.p: All patches are now installed on controller-0. Querying the current patch status displays the following information:

codeblock.systemoutput: Hostname IP Address Patch Current Reboot Required Release State ============ ============== ============= =============== ======= ===== compute-0 192.168.204.12 Yes No 15.12 idle controller-0 192.168.204.3 No No 15.12 idle controller-1 192.168.204.4 No Yes 15.12 idle

step.cmd: Install all pending patches on controller-1.

info.p: Repeat the previous step targeting controller-1.

stepresult.p: All patches are now installed on controller-1 as well. Querying the current patching status displays the following information:

codeblock.systemoutput: Hostname IP Address Patch Current Reboot Required Release State ============ ============== ============= =============== ======= ===== compute-0 192.168.204.12 Yes No 15.12 idle controller-0 192.168.204.3 Yes No 15.12 idle controller-1 192.168.204.4 Yes No 15.12 idle

step.cmd: Install any pending patches for the compute or storage hosts.

note.p: All VMs currently running on a compute host are live-migrated to another host. If this is not possible, the lock command fails. The Patch User can determine the reason for the failure and decide how to proceed. For example:

li.p: There may not be enough resources for the VMs on this host to live-migrate to another host, in which case:
you can remove any VMs on other hosts that are no longer required, or
There may be some VMs on the host being locked that cannot support live-migration due to their current setup, in which case you you can cold-migrate such VMs

info.p: If the Patch Current status for a compute or storage host is No, apply the pending patches using the following commands:
where hostname is the name of the host (for example, compute-0).

note.p: Patch installations can be triggered in parallel.

The sw-patch host-install-async command (install patches on the Web administration interface) can be run on all locked nodes, without waiting for one node to complete the install before triggering the install on the next. If you can lock the nodes at the same time, you can patch them at the same time. For maximum efficiency, you can migrate VMs to lock as many compute nodes at the same time as resources allow and patch at once, thereby reducing the overall time required to install a patch through the whole system.

Likewise, you can install a patch to the standby controller and a compute node at the same time. The only restrictions are those of the lock: You cannot lock both controllers, and you cannot lock a compute node if you do not have enough free resources to migrate the VMs off it. Also, in a CEPH configuration (with storage nodes), you cannot lock more than one of controller-0/controller-1/storage-0 at the same time, as these nodes are running CEPH monitors and you must have at least two in service at all times.

step.cmd: Confirm that all patches are installed and the Titanium Server cluster is up-to-date.

info.p: Use the sw-patch query command to verify that all patches are Applied.

codeblock.systemoutput: ï»¿ Patch ID Patch State ========================= =========== TITANIUM_15.12_PATCH_0001 Applied

info.p: If the Patch State for any patch is still shown as Available or Partial-Apply, use the sw-patch query-hosts command to identify which hosts are not Patch Current, and then apply patches to them as described in the preceding steps.

result.p: The Titanium cluster is up to date now. All patches are installed.
